content.body_md:
GitHub 101

Create Your First Repository (Online Only)

The simplest path: create a repo on github.com in minutes

A repository (repo) is like a folder on your computer. You put files and subfolders inside it. The difference: GitHub stores that folder on the internet so you can back it up, share it, and collaborate.

Online

Create a Repository on GitHub.com

No installs. Just your browser.

Step 1 ‚Äî Open the ‚ÄúNew repository‚Äù page

Go to github.com and sign in. Click the + button (top-right) ‚Üí New repository.

Step 2 ‚Äî Name your repo

In Repository name, type something simple, e.g. my-first-repo.
(Optional) Add a short Description.

Step 3 ‚Äî Choose visibility

Select Public (anyone can see it) or Private (only you and invited people).

Step 4 ‚Äî Initialize with a README

Check Add a README file. This gives your repo a helpful starting page and prevents it from being empty.

Step 5 ‚Äî (Optional) Add .gitignore and License

You can skip these for your first repo. Later, you can add a .gitignore (to ignore temp files) and a LICENSE (how others may use your work).

Step 6 ‚Äî Create the repository

Click Create repository. You‚Äôll land on your new repo‚Äôs page.

Step 7 ‚Äî Add files (upload in the browser)

Click Add file ‚Üí Upload files ‚Üí drag & drop files from your computer ‚Üí then click Commit changes to save them in the repo.

Step 8 ‚Äî Edit files online

Click a file (e.g., README.md) ‚Üí click the pencil icon ‚Üí make edits ‚Üí click Commit changes. That‚Äôs it ‚Äî you‚Äôve updated your repo.

Step 9 ‚Äî Share your repo

Copy the browser URL of your repo and share it. If it‚Äôs private, invite collaborators via Settings ‚Üí Collaborators.

lessons.title: Use GitHub Codespaces ‚Ä¢ Build, Run, Push

content.body_md:
Codespaces 101

Use GitHub Codespaces with Your Repository

Open a cloud dev environment, run a Python script, and push changes to GitHub

GitHub Codespaces lets you code in the browser (or VS Code) without installing anything on your computer. You‚Äôll open your repo in a Codespace, create a simple Python script, run it, then commit & push back to GitHub.

Step 1

Open a Codespace for Your Repo

Launch a ready-to-code environment in the cloud

1.1 ‚Äî Go to your repository

Open your repo page on github.com.

1.2 ‚Äî Open Codespaces

Click the green Code button ‚Üí Codespaces tab ‚Üí Create codespace on main. (If asked, keep the defaults.)

1.3 ‚Äî Wait for it to start

GitHub will prepare your environment. You‚Äôll see a VS Code-like interface in your browser with a built-in terminal.

Step 2

Create and Run a Simple Python Script

Test locally inside your Codespace

2.1 ‚Äî Create a new file

In the Explorer (left sidebar), click New File and name it hello.py. Paste the code below and save (Ctrl/Cmd + S). 

# hello.py
name = "Hawkar"
temps = [70, 75, 80]
avg = sum(temps) / len(temps)
print(f"Hello {name}! Average temp is {avg:.1f}¬∞F.")

2.2 ‚Äî Run the script in the Terminal

Open the terminal (Ctrl/Cmd + `) and run:

python3 hello.py
# or, depending on the image:
python hello.py

You should see the output printed below the command.

2.3 ‚Äî (Optional) Use packages

If you need a library, install it with pip:

pip install pandas

Then import it in your script and run again.

Step 3

Save Changes to GitHub (Commit & Push)

Use the built-in Source Control in Codespaces

3.1 ‚Äî Stage your changes

Click the Source Control icon (left sidebar). You‚Äôll see hello.py listed as a change. Click + (Stage Changes) next to it.

3.2 ‚Äî Commit

Enter a short message like ‚ÄúAdd hello.py test script‚Äù and click Commit.

3.3 ‚Äî Push

Click Sync Changes or Push in the Source Control panel. Your new file and commits are now on GitHub.

Prefer the terminal? You can run these commands instead:

git status
git add hello.py
git commit -m "Add hello.py test script"
git push
Step 4

Verify on GitHub

Confirm your file is in the repository

4.1 ‚Äî Refresh your repo page

Open your repository on github.com and refresh. You should see hello.py in the file list and your latest commit message.

Step 5

Stop or Reopen Your Codespace

Manage your environment easily

5.1 ‚Äî Stop (to save resources)

Click the green Code button ‚Üí You‚Äôll see (Active) status ‚Üí click the three dots (‚ãØ) ‚Üí select Stop codespace. You can reopen it anytime from the same menu.

¬© Hawkar ‚Äî Last updated

lessons.title: Streamlit in GitHub Codespaces ‚Ä¢ Build & Run

content.body_md:
Streamlit 101

Create & Run a Streamlit App in Codespaces

Zero local installs ‚Äî build in the browser and view via port forwarding

You‚Äôll open your repository in a GitHub Codespace, install Streamlit, create a simple app (app.py), run it on a forwarded port, and see it in your browser.

Step 1

Open Your Repository in a Codespace

Use the cloud dev environment

1.1 ‚Äî Go to your repository on GitHub

Open your repo page at github.com.

1.2 ‚Äî Launch Codespaces

Click the green Code button ‚Üí Codespaces tab ‚Üí Create codespace on main.

1.3 ‚Äî Wait for the editor

You‚Äôll see a VS Code-like editor in your browser with a built-in terminal at the bottom.

Step 2

Install Streamlit in the Codespace

One-time install in the container

2.1 ‚Äî Install via pip

In the terminal inside Codespaces, run:

pip install streamlit
Step 3

Create a Simple Streamlit App

Minimal UI with input, chart, and dataframe

3.1 ‚Äî New file: app.py

In the Explorer (left), click New File ‚Üí name it app.py and paste:

import streamlit as st
import pandas as pd

st.set_page_config(page_title="Hello Streamlit", page_icon="üëã", layout="centered")

st.title("Hello, Streamlit in Codespaces üëã")
st.write("This is a simple demo running entirely in your browser-based dev environment.")

name = st.text_input("Your name", "Hawkar")
temps = pd.DataFrame({"Temperature (¬∞F)": [70, 75, 80], "Humidity (%)": [30, 45, 50]})

st.subheader(f"Welcome, {name}!")
st.dataframe(temps)

st.line_chart(temps["Temperature (¬∞F)"])

if st.button("Compute Average Temp"):
    avg = temps["Temperature (¬∞F)"].mean()
    st.success(f"Average temperature is {avg:.1f}¬∞F")
Step 4

Run Streamlit and Open the App

Forward a port and view in your browser

4.1 ‚Äî Start Streamlit on a fixed port

From the terminal:

streamlit run app.py --server.address 0.0.0.0 --server.port 8000

The app will start on port 8000. Codespaces detects this and offers to open the port.

4.2 ‚Äî Open the forwarded port

If prompted, click Open in Browser. Or open the Ports panel (bottom), find port 8000, click the globe icon to open it.

4.3 ‚Äî (Optional) Make the port public for sharing

In the Ports panel, set the port visibility to Public to share the URL. (Keep it Private if you don‚Äôt want to share access.)

Step 5

Commit & Push Your Streamlit App

Save your work back to GitHub

5.1 ‚Äî Stage & Commit

Click the Source Control icon (left). Stage app.py with +, add a message like "Add Streamlit demo", then click Commit.

5.2 ‚Äî Push

Click Sync Changes or Push to upload your commit to GitHub.

Terminal alternative:

git status
git add app.py
git commit -m "Add Streamlit demo"
git push
Step 6

Verify on GitHub

Confirm your new file is in the repo

6.1 ‚Äî Check your repository

Refresh your repo page on github.com. You should see app.py and your latest commit.

¬© Hawkar ‚Äî Last updated

lessons.title: What is Streamlit? Why It Improves UI & UX

content.body_md:
Streamlit 101

What is Streamlit?

And why it helps the user interface and user experience of your code

Streamlit is an open-source Python library that turns scripts into interactive web apps ‚Äî with minimal effort and no need for frontend skills. Instead of showing results in plain terminal text, Streamlit makes it easy to build apps where users can explore, interact, and visualize data directly in the browser.

Benefits

Why Streamlit Improves UI & UX

Simple & Fast

Write Python only. No HTML, CSS, or JavaScript required ‚Äî yet you still get a professional-looking interface.

Interactive Widgets

Add sliders, dropdowns, text inputs, and buttons with one line of code, giving users control over your code‚Äôs behavior.

Data Visualization

Display charts, maps, and dataframes interactively ‚Äî much easier to understand than static console output.

Better UX for Sharing

Deploy your script as a web app so others can use it without installing Python or dependencies locally.

Explore

Learn More & Deploy Apps

With Streamlit, you can go beyond ‚Äúcode that runs‚Äù and deliver ‚Äúapps people enjoy using‚Äù. For more information and deployment options, visit:

https://streamlit.io/cloud

lessons.title: Streamlit in Codespaces ‚Ä¢ Visualize CSV Data

content.body_md:
Streamlit ‚Ä¢ Codespaces

Visualize a CSV with Streamlit in GitHub Codespaces

Repository layout ‚Üí CSV ‚Üí app.py ‚Üí run ‚Üí push

You will create a repo layout, add a small CSV file, write app.py to visualize it with Streamlit, run the app in your Codespace, and push the changes back to GitHub.

Step 1

Repository Structure

Minimal, clear layout

your-repo/
‚îú‚îÄ app.py
‚îú‚îÄ requirements.txt
‚îî‚îÄ data/
   ‚îî‚îÄ weather.csv
Step 2

Create Files

requirements.txt

streamlit
pandas

data/weather.csv

Date,Temperature,Humidity
2025-08-01,70,30
2025-08-02,75,45
2025-08-03,80,50
2025-08-04,85,60
2025-08-05,90,70
Step 3

app.py Script

Improved Streamlit script with caching, filtering, and safe summary

import streamlit as st
import pandas as pd
from pathlib import Path

st.set_page_config(page_title="CSV Viewer", page_icon="üìà", layout="centered")

DATA_PATH = Path("data") / "weather.csv"

st.title("CSV Viewer (Streamlit)")
st.caption("Reads data/weather.csv and shows a table, summary, and a line chart.")

@st.cache_data(show_spinner=False)
def load_csv(p: Path) -> pd.DataFrame | None:
    if not p.exists():
        return None
    df = pd.read_csv(p)
    if "Date" in df.columns:
        df["Date"] = pd.to_datetime(df["Date"], errors="coerce")
    return df

df = load_csv(DATA_PATH)

if df is None:
    st.error(f"CSV not found at {DATA_PATH}. Make sure the file exists.")
    st.stop()

# Raw data
st.subheader("Raw Data")
st.dataframe(df, width="stretch")  # ‚úÖ new API (replaces use_container_width)

# Summary (make it pandas-version-safe)
st.subheader("Summary Statistics")
numeric_cols = df.select_dtypes(include="number").columns.tolist()
if numeric_cols:
    summary = df[numeric_cols].describe()
    st.dataframe(summary, width="stretch")
else:
    st.info("No numeric columns found to summarize.")

# Optional date filter
has_dt = "Date" in df.columns and pd.api.types.is_datetime64_any_dtype(df["Date"])
if has_dt:
    dmin, dmax = df["Date"].min(), df["Date"].max()
    if pd.notna(dmin) and pd.notna(dmax):
        st.subheader("Filter")
        start, end = st.date_input(
            "Date range:",
            value=(dmin.date(), dmax.date()),
            min_value=dmin.date(),
            max_value=dmax.date(),
        )
        if start and end:
            mask = (df["Date"] >= pd.to_datetime(start)) & (df["Date"] <= pd.to_datetime(end))
            df = df.loc[mask].copy()

# Chart
st.subheader("Chart")
numeric_cols = df.select_dtypes(include="number").columns.tolist()
if not numeric_cols:
    st.warning("No numeric columns to plot.")
else:
    metric = st.selectbox("Select a numeric column to plot:", numeric_cols, index=0)
    if has_dt:
        chart_data = df.set_index("Date")[[metric]].sort_index()
    else:
        chart_data = df[[metric]]

    # ‚ùó Do NOT pass width="stretch" here ‚Äî Altair expects a number.
    # Also avoid use_container_width (deprecated). Let Streamlit auto-size.
    st.line_chart(chart_data)
Step 4

Run the App

In the Codespaces terminal:

pip install -r requirements.txt
streamlit run app.py --server.address 0.0.0.0 --server.port 8000

Click Open in Browser when prompted, or use the Ports panel ‚Üí port 8000.

Step 5

What You See When Running

  • A **title and caption** at the top: ‚ÄúCSV Viewer (Streamlit)‚Äù
  • A **data table** showing the contents of weather.csv
  • A **summary statistics table** (mean, min, max, etc.) for numeric columns
  • A **date filter widget** (calendar range) if the CSV has a Date column
  • A **chart section** where you can choose a numeric column (Temperature or Humidity) and see a line chart over time
  • Error/warning/info messages appear gracefully if columns are missing

In this example CSV, you can filter the date range (e.g., Aug 2‚ÄìAug 4), view the filtered table, summary statistics, and a line chart of Temperature or Humidity across dates.

¬© Hawkar ‚Äî Last updated

Streamlit UX

CSV Explorer ‚Äî User Experience

Upload/auto-load CSV ‚Üí Smart parsing ‚Üí Filter ‚Üí Explore ‚Üí Chart ‚Üí Export

This page documents the user experience of the improved CSV Explorer built with Streamlit. It runs in your existing repository (same Codespace), replacing the previous app.py.

Run

How to Run in GitHub Codespaces

Replace app.py ‚Üí install dependencies ‚Üí run Streamlit on a fixed port

1) Replace the app

Open your Codespace ‚Üí replace the existing app.py with the script below and save.

2) Ensure dependencies

Your requirements.txt should have at least:

streamlit
pandas

(Note: pandas pulls in numpy.)

3) Install & run

In the terminal:

pip install -r requirements.txt
streamlit run app.py --server.address 0.0.0.0 --server.port 8000

Click Open in Browser (or use the Ports panel ‚Üí globe icon on port 8000).

UX

What the User Experiences

Designed for clarity, speed, and reliability

  • Header & Caption. Clear page title and purpose.
  • Sidebar ‚Üí Data. Upload a CSV or automatically load data/weather.csv. If neither is present, a demo weather dataset is generated.
  • Smart datetime detection. Columns named like Date / Time / Timestamp / Datetime are auto-parsed. If none are detected, the user can try parsing a chosen column.
  • Chart options. Users multi-select metrics to plot, choose resampling (Daily/Weekly/Monthly), aggregation (Mean/Sum), rolling average window, normalization to 0‚Äì1, and chart type (Line/Area/Bar).
  • Raw Data table. Scrollable, searchable dataframe view.
  • Summary stats. Numeric columns summarized via describe().
  • KPIs. Quick metrics for row count and date-range boundaries when a datetime column is active.
  • Date range filter. When applicable, filter the dataset and reflect counts (‚ÄúShowing N rows from ‚Ä¶ to ‚Ä¶‚Äù).
  • Charts. Auto-sized charts of selected metrics; transformations (resample, rolling, normalize) apply in order.
  • Export. Download the current filtered view as filtered.csv.
  • Resilience. All critical operations are guarded with helpful error/warning/info messages so the UX never ‚Äúbreaks‚Äù.
Code

app.py (Exact Code Used)

Paste this into your repository‚Äôs app.py

import io
from pathlib import Path
from typing import Optional, Tuple, List

import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import streamlit as st

# ---------------- Page setup ----------------
st.set_page_config(page_title="CSV Explorer", page_icon="üìà", layout="centered")
st.title("üìà CSV Explorer")
st.caption("Load a CSV, filter by date, explore stats, and plot one or more metrics.")

# ---------------- Helpers ----------------
@st.cache_data(show_spinner=False)
def read_csv_safely(file_or_path) -> Optional[pd.DataFrame]:
    """Read CSV; coerce obvious datetime columns."""
    try:
        df = pd.read_csv(file_or_path)
        for col in df.columns:
            if col.lower() in ("date", "time", "timestamp", "datetime"):
                df[col] = pd.to_datetime(df[col], errors="coerce")
        return df
    except Exception as e:
        st.error(f"Could not read CSV: {e}")
        return None

@st.cache_data(show_spinner=False)
def demo_weather() -> pd.DataFrame:
    """Small synthetic time-series if no file is provided."""
    dates = pd.date_range("2024-01-01", periods=120, freq="D")
    x = np.arange(len(dates))
    df = pd.DataFrame(
        {
            "Date": dates,
            "TempC": 12 + 8 * np.sin(x / 9) + np.random.normal(0, 1.3, len(dates)),
            "Rain_mm": np.clip(np.random.gamma(1.5, 1.2, len(dates)) - 1.2, 0, None),
            "Wind_kmh": 10 + np.random.normal(0, 3, len(dates)),
        }
    )
    return df

def find_datetime_columns(df: pd.DataFrame) -> List[str]:
    return [c for c in df.columns if pd.api.types.is_datetime64_any_dtype(df[c])]

def numeric_columns(df: pd.DataFrame) -> List[str]:
    return df.select_dtypes(include="number").columns.tolist()

def filter_by_date(
    df: pd.DataFrame, date_col: str
) -> Tuple[pd.DataFrame, Optional[pd.Timestamp], Optional[pd.Timestamp]]:
    dmin, dmax = df[date_col].min(), df[date_col].max()
    if pd.isna(dmin) or pd.isna(dmax):
        st.info("Date column contains invalid values; showing all rows.")
        return df, None, None
    start, end = st.date_input(
        "Date range",
        value=(dmin.date(), dmax.date()),
        min_value=dmin.date(),
        max_value=dmax.date(),
        key="date_range",
    )
    if start and end:
        mask = (df[date_col] >= pd.to_datetime(start)) & (df[date_col] <= pd.to_datetime(end))
        return df.loc[mask].copy(), pd.to_datetime(start), pd.to_datetime(end)
    return df, None, None

def resample_df(df: pd.DataFrame, date_col: str, cols: List[str], freq: Optional[str], how: str) -> pd.DataFrame:
    if not freq:
        return df.set_index(date_col)[cols].sort_index()
    agg = "mean" if how == "Mean" else "sum"
    return df.set_index(date_col)[cols].sort_index().resample(freq).agg(agg)

def apply_rolling(df: pd.DataFrame, window: int) -> pd.DataFrame:
    return df.rolling(window, min_periods=1).mean() if window > 1 else df

def normalize_01(df: pd.DataFrame) -> pd.DataFrame:
    def _scale(s: pd.Series) -> pd.Series:
        mn, mx = s.min(), s.max()
        return (s - mn) / (mx - mn) if pd.notna(mn) and pd.notna(mx) and mx != mn else s * 0
    return df.apply(_scale, axis=0)

# ---------------- Sidebar: data & options ----------------
with st.sidebar:
    st.header("Data")
    uploaded = st.file_uploader("Upload CSV", type=["csv"])
    fallback_path = Path("data") / "weather.csv"

    if uploaded is not None:
        df = read_csv_safely(uploaded)
        source_label = "Uploaded file"
    elif fallback_path.exists():
        df = read_csv_safely(fallback_path)
        source_label = f"{fallback_path}"
    else:
        st.info("No file uploaded and no local CSV found ‚Äî using demo data.")
        df = demo_weather()
        source_label = "Demo dataset"

    if df is None or df.empty:
        st.error("No data to show.")
        st.stop()

    st.caption(f"Source: **{source_label}** ‚Ä¢ Rows: **{len(df):,}** ‚Ä¢ Columns: **{len(df.columns)}**")

    dt_cols = find_datetime_columns(df)
    if dt_cols:
        date_col = st.selectbox("Date column", dt_cols, index=0)
    else:
        st.warning("No datetime column detected. You can still chart numeric columns.")
        # Optional manual parse
        try_col = st.selectbox("Try parsing this column as dates (optional)", [""] + df.columns.tolist(), index=0)
        date_col = None
        if try_col != "":
            try:
                df[try_col] = pd.to_datetime(df[try_col], errors="coerce")
                if df[try_col].notna().any():
                    date_col = try_col
                    st.success(f"Parsed '{try_col}' as datetime.")
                else:
                    st.error(f"Parsing '{try_col}' produced all NaT.")
            except Exception as e:
                st.error(f"Failed to parse '{try_col}' as datetime: {e}")

    st.header("Chart Options")
    num_cols = numeric_columns(df)
    if not num_cols:
        st.warning("No numeric columns found.")
    selected_cols = st.multiselect("Metrics to plot", options=num_cols, default=num_cols[:1])

    freq = st.selectbox("Resample (if dated)", options=["Off", "D (Daily)", "W (Weekly)", "M (Monthly)"], index=0)
    freq_map = {"Off": None, "D (Daily)": "D", "W (Weekly)": "W", "M (Monthly)": "M"}
    agg = st.radio("Aggregation", ["Mean", "Sum"], horizontal=True, index=0)

    roll = st.slider("Rolling average window", min_value=1, max_value=60, value=1, help="Applies after resampling.")
    norm = st.checkbox("Normalize each series to 0‚Äì1", value=False)
    chart_kind = st.selectbox("Chart type", ["Line", "Area", "Bar"], index=0)

# ---------------- Raw data ----------------
st.subheader("Raw Data")
st.caption("Sort columns, use the search box, or scroll. (Editing disabled for safety.)")
st.dataframe(df, width="stretch")

# ---------------- Summary ----------------
st.subheader("Summary Statistics")
if num_cols:
    summary = df[num_cols].describe()  # pandas-version-safe
    st.dataframe(summary, width="stretch")
else:
    st.info("No numeric columns to summarize.")

# Quick KPIs (stringify dates to satisfy st.metric)
k1, k2, k3 = st.columns(3)
k1.metric("Rows", f"{len(df):,}")
if 'date_col' in locals() and date_col:
    dmin = pd.to_datetime(df[date_col].min())
    dmax = pd.to_datetime(df[date_col].max())
    start_str = str(dmin.date()) if pd.notna(dmin) else "‚Äî"
    end_str = str(dmax.date()) if pd.notna(dmax) else "‚Äî"
    k2.metric("Start", start_str)
    k3.metric("End", end_str)
else:
    k2.metric("Datetime", "Not set")
    k3.metric("‚Äî", "‚Äî")

# ---------------- Filtering ----------------
df_view = df.copy()
if 'date_col' in locals() and date_col:
    st.subheader("Filter")
    df_view, start_ts, end_ts = filter_by_date(df_view, date_col)
    if start_ts and end_ts:
        st.success(f"Showing {len[df_view):,} rows from {start_ts.date()} to {end_ts.date()}.")
    else:
        st.info(f"Showing all {len(df_view):,} rows.")

# ---------------- Chart ----------------
st.subheader("Chart")
if not selected_cols:
    st.warning("Pick at least one metric in the sidebar to plot.")
else:
    if 'date_col' in locals() and date_col:
        series_df = resample_df(df_view, date_col, selected_cols, freq_map[freq], agg)
    else:
        series_df = df_view[selected_cols]

    if series_df.empty:
        st.warning("Nothing to plot with the current filters.")
    else:
        if roll > 1:
            series_df = apply_rolling(series_df, roll)
        if norm:
            series_df = normalize_01(series_df)

        # Let Streamlit auto-size charts; don't pass width="stretch" (Altair expects a number)
        if chart_kind == "Line":
            st.line_chart(series_df)
        elif chart_kind == "Area":
            st.area_chart(series_df)
        else:
            st.bar_chart(series_df)

# ---------------- Export ----------------
st.subheader("Export")
csv_bytes = df_view.to_csv(index=False).encode("utf-8")
st.download_button(
    "Download current view as CSV",
    data=csv_bytes,
    file_name="filtered.csv",
    mime="text/csv",
)
st.caption("Export respects the current date filter (if any).")

# ---------------- Footer tip ----------------
st.caption("Tip: Upload any CSV in the sidebar. If your dates aren‚Äôt recognized, choose a column to parse as datetime.")

Note: HTML escapes were added only where needed for safe rendering.

¬© Hawkar ‚Äî Last updated

Video

Organize Your App into Pages ‚Äî Walkthrough

Watch first, then copy the code below.

Streamlit UX

Organize Your Streamlit App into Pages

Navigation in the sidebar ‚Üí Home ‚Ä¢ Visualization ‚Ä¢ Data View

You can improve user experience by splitting your Streamlit app into **pages** using a simple sidebar radio selector. The script below adds a Home overview, a rich Visualization page, and a flexible Data View page ‚Äî all within one file.

Run

Use This in Your Repo (Codespaces)

Replace app.py ‚Üí install ‚Üí run on a fixed port

1) Replace your app

Open your Codespace and replace app.py with the code below.

2) Dependencies

Ensure requirements.txt contains at least:

streamlit
pandas
numpy

3) Install & run

pip install -r requirements.txt
streamlit run app.py --server.address 0.0.0.0 --server.port 8000

Then click Open in Browser (or use the Ports panel ‚Üí port 8000).

Code

app.py (Multi-Page ‚Äî Exact Code)

Paste this as-is into your repository‚Äôs app.py

import io
from pathlib import Path
from typing import Optional, Tuple, List

import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import streamlit as st

# =========================
# Page setup
# =========================

@st.cache_data(show_spinner=False)
def read_csv_from_bytes(content: bytes) -> Optional[pd.DataFrame]:
    """Read CSV from uploaded bytes; coerce obvious datetime columns."""
    try:
        df = pd.read_csv(io.BytesIO(content))
        df = coerce_common_datetime_cols(df)
        return df
    except Exception as e:
        st.error(f"Could not read uploaded CSV: {e}")
        return None


@st.cache_data(show_spinner=False)
def read_csv_from_path(path_str: str) -> Optional[pd.DataFrame]:
    """Read CSV from local path; coerce obvious datetime columns."""
    try:
        df = pd.read_csv(path_str)
        df = coerce_common_datetime_cols(df)
        return df
    except Exception as e:
        st.error(f"Could not read CSV at {path_str}: {e}")
        return None


@st.cache_data(show_spinner=False)
def demo_dataset() -> pd.DataFrame:
    """Synthetic time-series if no file is provided."""
    dates = pd.date_range("2024-01-01", periods=180, freq="D")
    x = np.arange(len(dates))
    return pd.DataFrame(
        {
            "Date": dates,
            "TempC": 15 + 7 * np.sin(x / 10) + np.random.normal(0, 1.4, len(dates)),
            "Rain_mm": np.clip(np.random.gamma(1.8, 1.0, len(dates)) - 1.0, 0, None),
            "Wind_kmh": 12 + np.random.normal(0, 3, len(dates)),
        }
    )


def coerce_common_datetime_cols(df: pd.DataFrame) -> pd.DataFrame:
    """Coerce columns named like dates into datetime (nonfatal)."""
    for col in df.columns:
        name = str(col).lower()
        if name in ("date", "time", "timestamp", "datetime"):
            df[col] = pd.to_datetime(df[col], errors="coerce")
    return df


def find_datetime_columns(df: pd.DataFrame) -> List[str]:
    return [c for c in df.columns if pd.api.types.is_datetime64_any_dtype(df[c])]


def numeric_columns(df: pd.DataFrame) -> List[str]:
    return df.select_dtypes(include="number").columns.tolist()


def filter_by_date(
    df: pd.DataFrame, date_col: str
) -> Tuple[pd.DataFrame, Optional[pd.Timestamp], Optional[pd.Timestamp]]:
    dmin, dmax = df[date_col].min(), df[date_col].max()
    if pd.isna(dmin) or pd.isna(dmax):
        st.info("Date column contains invalid values; showing all rows.")
        return df, None, None
    start, end = st.date_input(
        "Date range",
        value=(dmin.date(), dmax.date()),
        min_value=dmin.date(),
        max_value=dmax.date(),
        key="date_range",
    )
    if start and end:
        mask = (df[date_col] >= pd.to_datetime(start)) & (df[date_col] <= pd.to_datetime(end))
        return df.loc[mask].copy(), pd.to_datetime(start), pd.to_datetime(end)
    return df, None, None


def resample_df(df: pd.DataFrame, date_col: str, cols: List[str], freq: Optional[str], how: str) -> pd.DataFrame:
    if not freq:
        return df.set_index(date_col)[cols].sort_index()
    agg = "mean" if how == "Mean" else "sum"
    return df.set_index(date_col)[cols].sort_index().resample(freq).agg(agg)


def apply_rolling(df: pd.DataFrame, window: int) -> pd.DataFrame:
    return df.rolling(window, min_periods=1).mean() if window and window > 1 else df


def normalize_01(df: pd.DataFrame) -> pd.DataFrame:
    def _scale(s: pd.Series) -> pd.Series:
        mn, mx = s.min(), s.max()
        return (s - mn) / (mx - mn) if pd.notna(mn) and pd.notna(mx) and mx != mn else s * 0
    return df.apply(_scale, axis=0)

    # Filter by date if available

    has_dt = bool(date_col)
    if has_dt:
        st.subheader("Filter")
        df_view, start_ts, end_ts = filter_by_date(df_view, date_col)
        if start_ts and end_ts:
            st.success(f"Showing {len(df_view):,} rows from {start_ts.date()} to {end_ts.date()}.")
        else:
            st.info(f"Showing all {len(df_view):,} rows.")

    # Chart config from sidebar (already defined)
    selected_cols = locals().get("selected_cols", num_cols_all[:1])
    freq_choice = locals().get("freq_choice", "Off")
    freq_map = {"Off": None, "D (Daily)": "D", "W (Weekly)": "W", "M (Monthly)": "M"}
    agg = locals().get("agg", "Mean")
    roll = int(locals().get("roll", 1))
    norm = bool(locals().get("norm", False))
    chart_kind = locals().get("chart_kind", "Line")

    if not selected_cols:
        st.warning("Pick at least one metric in the sidebar to plot.")
        st.stop()

    # Build series
    if has_dt:
        series_df = resample_df(df_view, date_col, selected_cols, freq_map[freq_choice], agg)
    else:
        series_df = df_view[selected_cols]

    if series_df.empty:
        st.warning("Nothing to plot with the current settings.")
        st.stop()

    if roll > 1:
        series_df = apply_rolling(series_df, roll)
    if norm:
        series_df = normalize_01(series_df)

    # Render chart (let Streamlit auto-size to avoid Altair width schema issues)
    st.subheader("Chart")

        st.line_chart(series_df)
    elif chart_kind == "Area":

    else:
